overview: From 2025-11-01 to 2025-12-01, ethereum-optimism/ecosystem had 2 new PRs (2 merged), 2 new issues, and 48 active contributors.

topIssues.title: autogen docs script in eth-optimism/viem is not printing nested objects correctly
topIssues.author: tremarkley

topIssues.title: Superchain relayer is broken for lisk
topIssues.author: tremarkley
topIssues.body:
This tx cannot be relayed This is his txn
https://blockscout.lisk.com/tx/0xf89e8a7afc295e232ee9fb29204ab1c47a46a0bc906eab1c58050f191713072c

topPRs.title: chore: update viem chain definitions to latest state from superchain-registry
topPRs.author: tremarkley
topPRs.body:
Part of https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ecosystem/issues/967

The chain definition for Lisk is out of date and therefore the superchain relayer is failing to relay messages for it. This PR updates all chain definitions to be in sync with the latest definitions in the superchain-registry. As part of this I also removed the interop devnet and alphanet chain definitions, since those chains have been spun down.

topPRs.title: Version Packages
topPRs.author: opgitgovernance
topPRs.body:
This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.


# Releases
## @eth-optimism/autorelayer-interop@0.0.25

### Patch Changes

-   Updated dependencies \[[`0d137a4`](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ecosystem/commit/0d137a4bad2982ea2a33ef5dcc7f1baeef0de1f7)]:

topContributors.summary: devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving the quality and clarity of documentation and contract specifications for the Ethereum Optimism project. They made several impactful enhancements to the specifications, most notably by linking defined terms to their definitions in a large refactor (`specs#856`, +274/-225 lines), adding a new `SuperFaultDisputeGame` variant (`specs#852`), and cleaning up existing contract specs (`specs#853`, `specs#854`). This was complemented by a broad effort across 12 separate pull requests to fix typos and grammatical errors throughout the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository, demonstrating a clear focus on improving overall documentation and specification quality.

sbvegan: Focused on critical documentation and registry updates, merging 12 PRs to support network communications and upgrades. They executed a major update to notice pages for communications in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1847` (+2155/-698 lines) and managed key details for the Jovian hard fork, including updating release information in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1852`. In addition to these direct contributions, sbvegan was an active collaborator, providing 25 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on maintaining and improving project documentation.

ajsutton: Focused on supporting the team through collaboration this month. They contributed to project progress by providing 3 pull request reviews, which included 2 approvals. Additionally, they participated in discussions by commenting on one issue.
joshklop: No activity this month.

Vaios0x: Focused on proposing a broad set of enhancements for the `op-node` component within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, opening 33 pull requests this month. The proposed work includes significant new features such as a retry system with exponential backoff (#18116), improved context and timeout management (#18118), and enhanced error handling (#18113). Additionally, Vaios0x submitted comprehensive architecture documentation (#18117) and numerous other documentation improvements, though none of this work has been merged.

sebastianst: Focused on significant refactoring and modularization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository to improve its core architecture. They led this effort by moving fork names into a new package (#18121) and relocating package predeploys (#18145), both substantial architectural changes. Alongside this refactoring, sebastianst also fixed a configuration loading bug in the batch decoder (#18209) and actively supported the team by providing 17 code reviews.
Inphi: No activity this month.
geoknee: Contributed by reviewing and approving one pull request.

smartcontracts: Focused on improving CI processes and contributing to future design this month, merging a pull request to enhance upgrade tests in CI (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18133). They also authored a significant design document for OPCM v2 (ethereum-optimism/design-docs#353) and were highly engaged in supporting the team's work, providing 30 code reviews. Their contributions show a focus on development infrastructure, design, and team collaboration.

mds1: Focused on CI and deployment pipeline maintenance this month, merging 6 small PRs to address bugs and configuration issues. Their contributions included updating CLI flags for the op-deployer (optimism#18143) and renaming CI jobs to align with required checks (optimism#18139). In addition to their own fixes, mds1 was an active collaborator, providing 19 code reviews for teammates. This activity shows a primary focus on bug fixes and configuration changes to ensure system stability.

nonsense: Focused on improving the reliability and efficiency of the Optimism stack, merging four pull requests across multiple repositories. Their most impactful contributions included restricting the transaction mempool to trusted peers in `ethereum-optimism/op-geth#719` and executing a significant refactor of the `op-batcher` in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18174`. In addition to their own code, they supported the team by providing 6 code reviews. Their work was primarily focused on feature enhancements and bug fixes, with changes distributed across both application code and tests.

opgitgovernance: This month, opgitgovernance focused on automated maintenance and improving test stability across repositories. They opened pull requests in `optimism` to address test flakiness (#18106, #18107) and submitted automated code generation updates to `superchain-registry` (#1137, #1138). Additionally, they generated automated metrics reports by opening and closing two issues in the `docs` repository (#1825, #1826), with their code changes primarily touching tests and configuration files.

ccerv1: Focused on generating and refining results within the `ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding` repository this month. They delivered multiple large-scale data updates, including draft results for QA (PR #82) and a significant post-backfill update involving over 34k lines added and removed (PR #84). Additionally, ccerv1 resolved an important issue with the retroactive calculation logic for projects affected by downtime (PR #83), demonstrating a focus on both bug fixes and data management.

axelKingsley: Focused on developing the `op-supernode` component, merging a key feature PR in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#18141) to implement runnable and RPC activities with a heartbeat example. They continued this effort with three additional open PRs to expand `op-supernode` functionality, including a Superroot API and P2P capabilities. In addition to their implementation work, they supported the team by providing 5 code reviews. Axel's code contributions this month were primarily focused on new feature work, with smaller efforts dedicated to bugfixes and documentation.

AmadiMichael: Focused on significant code cleanup and refactoring within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository this month. Their primary contribution was merging PR #18122, a substantial refactor that removed the "DeployProxy" and 549 lines of code. In addition to this work, they were an active reviewer, providing 7 reviews across the project. This activity reflects a primary focus on bug fixes, with changes impacting both code and test files.

pcw109550: Focused on node synchronization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, proposing a significant Proof of Concept for a "Light CL" in `op-node` (optimism#18196). In support of this effort, they identified and created three issues related to node syncing and potential bugs (#18124, #18125, #18126). While their primary development work was on this open PR, they also actively supported the team by conducting 14 code reviews. Their code changes, which modified 34 files, were primarily focused on bug fixes and tests.

maurelian: This month, maurelian focused on development tooling and new features, merging a PR to optimize the build process in `op-deployers` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18130). They also proposed a new `DeployFeesDepositor` script (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18223) and provided significant team support by conducting 16 code reviews. Based on their code changes, their work was primarily centered on feature development and testing.

bitwiseguy: This month, bitwiseguy focused on maintaining the deployment tooling, with their primary contribution being the support for the `op-contracts/v5.0.0-rc.2` upgrade in the `op-deployer` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18154). They also fixed related test timeouts in the CLI runner via PR ethereum-optimism/optimism#18179. In addition to their own changes, they actively supported the team by providing 8 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on bug fixes and testing within the deployment process.

aliersh: Focused on repository maintenance and developer experience, merging three pull requests this month. Their most impactful contribution was a refactor in ethereum-optimism/optimism#18212 that removed a 157-line script, simplifying the codebase. They also improved repository organization by moving specifications in ethereum-optimism/specs#851 and enhanced CI guidance for developers in ethereum-optimism/optimism#18127. This work, along with 5 code reviews, demonstrates a focus on refactoring and bug fixes, with changes primarily affecting test files.

tremarkley: This month, tremarkley executed a significant maintenance task by updating Viem chain definitions in the `ethereum-optimism/ecosystem` repository. They merged a single, large-scale pull request (#966) which introduced over 6,200 lines of changes across 368 files to bring definitions to their latest state. Alongside this core contribution, they identified and created two new issues (#967, #968) and actively supported the team by providing nine code reviews. Their work was primarily focused on tests and documentation to ensure ecosystem integrity.

alcueca: This month, alcueca focused on security hardening by addressing audit findings for Safer Safes in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They merged two pull requests to implement these fixes (#18147, #18172), with the latter involving over 950 lines of changes. In addition to this work, they also provided 4 code reviews. Their contributions were primarily classified as bug fixes, with modifications concentrated in configuration and test files.

JosepBove: Focused on operational maintenance in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository, merging two PRs to update an RPC configuration and apply a bugfix for betanets (#1281, #1280). They were also an active collaborator, providing 7 reviews and 5 comments on other pull requests. Their contributions were primarily focused on bug fixes and other work, with a third of their file modifications involving documentation.

its-everdred: Focused on a significant documentation initiative this month, authoring a substantial pull request to add Actions SDK reference pages in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1857`. This in-progress work represents a large effort, with over 10,000 lines of additions across 100 files. Alongside this primary contribution, they remained engaged with the team's work by providing 9 code reviews. Their activity was concentrated on documentation and configuration files.

scharissis: Focused on maintenance and reliability within the acceptance testing framework this month. They merged several small PRs for chores and CI fixes, including updating a dependency version in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18120` and correcting a CI token in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18156`. Additionally, scharissis proactively identified and created issues to address a flaky test (`#17548`) and report unused tests (`#16273`). Their contributions centered on test and configuration file modifications.

They added new configuration sections for `minBaseFee` and `DA Footprint` (docs#1830) and authored a new guide on setting the minimum base fee (docs#1849). In addition to this documentation work, ZakAyesh contributed 4 code reviews and has an open pull request to add a key handback task in `superchain-ops` (#1284).

Additionally, they identified a potential bug in the `op-deployer`'s superchain configuration proxy by opening issue #18123. This work, primarily classified as bugfixes, involved changes across 14 code and test files.

While this work remains unmerged, it represents a significant effort involving over 48,000 lines of additions across 833 files. The changes show a primary focus on feature work and modifications to configuration files.
